comments:
This course focuses on the creative side of mathematics, with an emphasis on
discovery, reasoning, proofs and effective communication, while at the same time
studying real and complex numbers, sequences, series, continuity, differentiability and
integrability. Small class sizes permit an informal, discussion-type atmosphere, and often
the entire class works together on a given problem. Homework is intended to be thought
provoking, rather than skill sharpening.
Many students felt this course was “a good introduction,” featuring a variety of
topics. One student reported that MATH 202 was “very useful.” Some students
complained that the course material could be “dry” though. Some students expected a
seminar style class, but one student recognized “the biggest concern was always to write
everything down, so we could do the homework.” One student noted they “learned a
tremendous amount and made a real jump in… mathematical ability.”
Students agreed Professor Lieberman was “fairly engaging, but the lecturing style
was sometimes monotonous.” One student noted, “Professor Lieberman was able to
communicate the ideas to the class in a very clear manner.” Another student felt
“Professor Lieberman’s style was perfect.”
One student suggested that “only math majors or minors should take this course.”
Another felt “computer science majors should all be recommended to take it as
freshmen.” Students agreed that “unless you are a math major or accustomed to thinking
in that way, this course can be very difficult.”
